Kneeling and praying him to give her pardon;
Told him indeed 'twas she that sought his head,
And that she thought, that being now a Queen,
She might by her prerogative take heads,
Whose and as many as she listed: but
She promised she would send it him again,
Or else Petruccio's first: or if he would forgive her
This time, she'd do so no more.
He seemed he would not hear her: than she beat
Herself against the walls and floor, and flies
To free herself by th' windows: calls for poison,
Knife, rope, or any thing, whereby to follow
Her most abused father. What to make on't,
As I am true to th' crown, I must refer
Only unto your majesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O 'tis fearful!

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: My lord, you saw not th' apparition, did you?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Not I: I saw him not: nor has the devil
Power in a traitor's shadow to appear
Unto a loyal subject. Ha! my loyalty
And truth unto the crown defend me!
See the very foresaid devil at my elbow,
Head and all now: avoid, attempt me not Satan,
I do conjure thee by all the virtues of a loyal courtier.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: They are all too weak to charm a devil sir;
But me they may, your friend.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I defy thee bubsebel.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: What do you see, my lord?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Look there, the apparition, there it is;
As like the traitor Sforza when he lived,
As devil can be like a devil — o!

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Fear not: he lives, and loyal to the King.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Does the King say so?

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Give me your hand my lord,
The King will say so, if this be flesh and blood.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Ay, if thou beest flesh and blood: but how to believe that I know not, when my touch makes me sweat out a whole shower of pure loyalty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No more, Horatio: I find that my credulity
Has been wrought on unto my much abuse,
And Sforza now appears an honest man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Whoever thought otherwise? or how
Could he in nature appear less than loyal?
O my right noble lord, I weep thy welcome.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Back soldiers, to your duty: learn of me
Hereafter how to judge with equity.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Long live the King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now in the midst of my soul-frighting objects,
I cannot but applaud your mutual friendship.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes, and how equally I affect them both.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O that mischance propitiously might be
A light to reconcile my thoughts and me.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: May you be pleased sir then to let the cause
In which your injured Queen, your son and I,
And truth itself have suffered, be reviewed?
The mischievous creature that was drunk, now's mad
With brain-confounding strong ambition:
She whom your ill-placed love graced as a wife,
Whom now I am not fond of to call daughter,
It seems is past examination.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Mad, mad, most irrecoverably mad.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: But let those hellbred witnesses be called,
And re-examined.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: They are not to be found.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No? where is flavello?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Not seen in court these ten days.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Let me out-squeeze that court-sponge.
If I do not fetch out the poisonous corruption
Of all this practice, let me yet be guilty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: From whence art thou?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: Your province of Palermo
Thus low submits in duty to your highness,
The service and the lives of whose inhabitants
So truly are subjected to your power,
That needless is the preparation
Which with much grief we hear you make against us,
By hostile force to root up a rebellion
Bred merely out of rumour.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Peace, no more:
I find the province loyal.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Who made doubt on't?
I'll undertake to find more toads in Ireland,
Than rebels in Palermo, were the Queen
(Queen did I call her?) that disloyal woman
And that sly traitor Lodovico out on't.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: See Sforza, see Petruccio, what Lodovico
That trusty and true-hearted lord has written me:
He has ended all my doubts, good man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Ah, ah! does not your grace come to me now?
I thought I would put your highness to't for once,
To try what you would say: when Lodovico
Does not prove trusty, then let me be trussed.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: 'Tis a most happy information.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ay, do you note the passages?

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: 'Tis indeed worthy a King's regard: you see your way.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yes, yes, I know now what to do,
And mean to put it presently in act.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: This I foresaw would prove an hour of comfort.
The stars themselves ne'er saw events more plainly.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How full of april-changes is our life?
Now a fit shower of sad distilling rain,
And by and by the sun breaks forth again.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Fear not good madam, trust my care and reason.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Good Lodovico, though I thank your care
And love to me, yet give me leave to doubt,
That as that cruel and ambitious woman
Hath overswayed the judgement of the King,
She may pervert his royal purposes
Of peace and love, to your and my destruction.
Before you sent, would you had ta'en my counsel.
sp.stage: Enter Pedro with Gonzago, and letters.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: To end all doubts, see Pedro is returned.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: And happily: see madam.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: My Gonzago;
My prince, I should have said.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Thrice-gracious mother,
I thank Petruccio, who preserved my life,
For nothing more, than this one minute's bliss,
In which I find your blessing in a kiss.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Weep not, fair sir.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: The lord Petruccio madam
Presents you these.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Welcome my sweet young prince.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: I thank you Lodovico.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Now I see methinks a court again.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: We shall do shortly; for the King is coming,
And not in terror, but with grace and favour.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: 'Tis happy heavenly news.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: See here's an inundation
Of joys that do like waves o'ercome each other.
Brave, wise, and valiant Petruccio!
That couldst so happily deceive the King
By a supposed death, to save the life
Of my sweet boy: all that I can be sorry for,
Is this: Alinda is frantic.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: Can that grieve you?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: He brings her with him: and I hope the change
Of air, with wholesome prayers and physics art,
In which I am not ignorant, may restore her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Madam, the sun shines fairly.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: News, news upon news!

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: The Queen is killed: is not that it?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: No nor the King neither, God bless him: they are both alive, with all their pomp and train coming to see our school-mistress.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: Auspicious providence!

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: They take us in their way, for they are passing to Nicosia, where the King means to keep his word with the Queen, in giving her three what d'ye calls?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Three boons, as the custom is.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Boons? I boons: I warrant she'll ask no baubles.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: O mistress, you were careful for her, that comes
I warrant but to jeer you.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Patience would die, if 'twere not exercised.
But now it rests, that we prepare to entertain our guests.
We must to welcome them make holy day,
And give our scholars leave to feast and play.
The swains you say are perfect in the dance;
So are my maids: we'll leave it for the King.

div.head: Scoen. iii.
div.stage: Enter King, Alinda, Horatio, Lodovico, attendants.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I cannot but applaud your mind, Alinda,
But am not much affected with the subject
On which you purpose now to cast your favour.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: More scorn upon my life, and rude vexation.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: If my fair meaning sir shall prove mistaken,
'Tis but a loving purpose lost.
(Oh that wretch flavello!)

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: If she have further purpose than to raise
More sorrow by the King's displeasure to her.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Let her alone, her reign's but short we know.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Is this the sound of want and misery?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Of wantonness I fear, and luxury.
(The villain had no purpose but to flatter.)
O sir, why came we hither?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Mark the chameleon.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Tis most sweet music.

div.head: Scoen. iv.
div.stage: Enter Eulalia with three or four girls, and work in their hands.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Such as the rudeness of the country yields sir,
Hail to the King and Queen, and may the thanks
Which on my knees I offer at those feet
That beautify and bless this humble earth
Add many years unto your happy lives.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: We have e'en seen enough: 'twas all I feared,
To find her knee-deep in hypocrisy.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Seem not to turn away, most gracious madam,
Before I show for which I hoped you came,
The manner how I get a competence to live.
sp.stage: [shows her works, and makes a brave description of pieces: as Sale-work, daywork, nightwork, wrought nightcaps, coyfs, stomachers.]

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Your work you say, though't be o'th' newest frame,
I fear your play is still at the old game.
Both ways bring money: is't not so forsooth?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Enough, Alinda.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Too much, to tread upon affliction.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What say you Lodovico?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I say sir, the distresses of that lady merit a
King's pity, and not such scorn
As I see cast upon her: but the best are women.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: May it please your highness sit, and note the play
By which we gain when we lay work away.
The song I taught you last.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: These wenches will be a good help to you at wassail-tide.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: We have variety for all the seasons,
Of such poor entertainments, mighty Queen,
To show our much contentment in their welcome.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Goodness speaks in her.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: There's for your song () no, stay, I may transgress
The law.

sp.speaker: (Lod.
sp.l: O devil!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Let her jeer on.)

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Not if you give it for her pains, Alinda.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Nay since you warrant it, let's pay and go.
Though I have heard such pains disputed begging.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: As all arts are, by the rewards they find.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Nay I beseech your majesties.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: What's the feat now?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Sir, are you pleased to prosecute your journey?
Or do these beauties and delights enchant you?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ha? no, come, let's away.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: O let me yet entreat your highness stay.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Not a stroke more I thank you: we have heard
And seen enough: so much, as I must tell you
I cannot but commend your parents wisdom,
Who having calculated your nativity,
By which they had the foresight of your fall,
Prevented thus the planets by their care,
By teaching you to live by hand and foot.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Did ever daughter of a King thus suffer?
Or has she pride to smile on injuries?

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: Sir, you forget Nicosia.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Plots against me?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: She dreams of treason intended against me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: No divination against her own good, I hope.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Mighty sir, hear me: not to implore your bounty;
No not your thanks, nor popular applause;
But for I am your subject and your servant,
Bound by your allegiance as well to prevent
All ills might pass against you, as to do none.
I could not think it but strict duty in me
To hasten this discovery.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Treason, and a letter?
We have never a false brother amongst us, have we?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: If ever you held your peace, peace now.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It bears a face of horror.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Cunning and Gipsy tricks: will you to Nicosia?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What we meant there, we may do here as well.
The treason's there intended: look ye my lords!
How careless is this woman of her safety.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: You sir are careless: for if there be danger,
Where can I fear it but in this place only?
The world holds not an enemy of mine,
But this enchantress you maintain against me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Your motion and your own love drew us hither.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I would fain love her, and certainly I should,
But that she still begets fresh cause of hatred.
She has some devilish plot in hand this instant:
This show is but the straw that hides the pit.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No enemy but she? to let her know she lies,
Even unto profanation against that lady,
I'll speak.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I hope you will not.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The King shall see his error.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Will you?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: She her cruelty.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Will you, will you?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The world Eulalia's piety.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Will you? will you?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What says Lodovico?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Most mighty sir, we here confess and say.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: We? you hear not me say any thing; do you?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What will you say?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: That letter was not ours.

sp.speaker: Hor
sp.l: That's well.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We easily believe it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nor any day or place as yet set down
Among ourselves, for fact against the Queen.
I mean Alinda.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Nor fact intended was there, of death or danger?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: 'Twas wished at least by us.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Lord, lord,
Lord mum.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Our guard.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: King she's the general grudge of all thy kingdom.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: You do not hear me say so.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Their grudge incites my love: take 'em away.
Come my wronged Alinda: this place shall serve,
And this assembly, to make a King's word good.
Make your demands: three things I promise you.
Ask what you will, even to my dearest blood.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Your highness will excuse me, if I urge you
To bind it with an oath?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Give me a book.
What I have promised to my lawful Queen,
I will perform; ask freely.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Great Queen, vouchsafe to take an admonition,
My last and truest testimony of love.
The rest were shadows to it.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Well, pray let's hear it.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Let your demands be for the common good.
Not for your own respects: self-love may hurt you:
Beware ambition, envy, and revenge.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The oracle could not pronounce more wisely.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Is this your love? 'tis fear of my just vengeance.
Therefore hear my demands, my King and husband.
First I demand the lives of these conspirators
Lodovico and Horatio.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Bloody.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Next that your son, much of the mother's nature,
By act of parliament be disinherited.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: O fearful.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Last, that this woman have her eyes put out,
And be for ever banished your dominions.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Cruelty and ingratitude passed all example

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Was this your charity? you have now declared it fully:
And I of both have made sufficient trial.
Come here Eulalia, take now thy wonted seat and keep it ever.
Thy poverty and patience have restored thee
By the just providence: while her excess and pride
Casts her before thee, to receive that doom
She had devised 'gainst thy immortal goodness.
Into perpetual exile; hence, away with her.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: Remember your oath, my lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My oath was to perform what I had promised unto my lawful Queen: that's my Eulalia.
And let good Lodowick and Horatio be restored.
sp.stage: Exeunt King and attendants Alinda entranced carried out.

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.l: Oh! proh! proh nef as!
I'll have no hand in blood of any man.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: More exclamations? what distracts you now?

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.l: Coram senatures acta est: sub judice lis est.
Ocurvae in terris animae: the rustics
Have ta'en again the law into their hands.
And will you tender clemency non justante
A courtier hang, his sweet face nec invante.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: What is his name?

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.l: His name is hight Alphonso
That treason brought in pectore and Skonso

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Who are the heads of the judicious faction?

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.l: Andrea, Lollio, Poggio, the drudges
Have got the people's voice to their judges.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Dare they do this?

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.l: Yes judges they will be,
And kill, they say, the snake of treachery.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: I hope we may come yet to stay their sentence.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Pray bring us to the place: where if we can,
Let us avert their judgement from this man.

div.head: Scoen. vi.
div.stage: Enter Andrea, Poggio, Lollio, a typstaff before them.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: And can these turmoils never have an end?
Unless we load our heads and shoulders thus
Our bodies eke with justice capa pe.
And pepper all our brains with policy.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: 'Twas time to have a care: ay, and a piteous care.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: A pious care you mean.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Well pious then:
You'll show your own wit, whose clothes soever you wear
(So do the wits of the time) but as I said,
'tis time we have a care, for though our Queen,
Our school mistress I would say, be mercifully, idleful
It is fit that we be prejudicious in the state.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Judicious brother.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Jew in your face.
Trip me again?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Agree upon't, brother sages of the bench.
My brother Poggio here said very well
And learnedly and as I would have said myself?
(If you will take his meaning) to wit that as
Our shool mistress dotes upon
Clemency, it is fit that we run mad upon cruelty
Something her in the midst, we shall jump into the saddle of justice.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: I do say so, without all peradventure
For if the candle of her mercy be not put out,
We shall shortly, see more honest men than knaves among us.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: More knaves you mean brother.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: I mean no more knaves than yourself, brother.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Agree again, sage brothers of the bench: and let no private
Itch grow to a put like scab.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Then the point:
Do not I understand the purpose of our meeting
Here in our petty parliament, if I may so call it?
Is it nor for a reformation, to pull down
The Queen's mercy, and set up our justice?
For the prevention of a superabundance of treason
Daily practised against her?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Most true. And is it fit therefore that you brabble among yourselves, and leave all worse than you found it?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: No, we will make such a reformation, that treason shall not dare to peep over the hedge of her dominion, but we will take it by the nose and punish it indignly: most indignly will we punish it?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: All this I grant: but before we sit and bustle on the bench, because it is, and that without all peradventure, the first time that ever we played so wise a part, is it not fit to take advice among ourselves, how to deform ourselves in our office.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: De did you say? in in you should say.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: In with your horns: how now?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Nay brothers o'th bench.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Does he think to control me? because he has been a sexton, and a little more book learned then a lay man with an amen forsooth?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Nay brothers: this will control the business.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Or because he has been in many a man's grave before him, does he think no man so deep in grave matters as himself?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Well, I forbear.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Shall he bid me in, in? as if I were not his inferior?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: I forbear still.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: I will show myself his inferior I, and a greater man than he; and to prove myself a great man, let him hang one, I will save two.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Still orbear.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Pray brothers yet agree: and remember we use no mercy

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Let him that uses any mercy lack mercy, for my part.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Then let us sit, and fall to the business.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Sit and fall: was that so wisely spoken of a book-learned man now?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Still I forbear passion becomes not judges,
Now bring in the offender, the new and last offender.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Pray think on your speeches.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: I have made speeches that I hope shall make traitors.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Ashamed to wear their own heads on their shoulders.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p:
A traitor's head is not his own head: 'tis forfeited by law to
the King; 'tis the King's head.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: I say a traitor's head is his own head: and a good subjects head is the King's head.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: I say that's treason: and the head thou wearest is not thine own then, if thou beest a good subject.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Wilt thou tell me that?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Passion becomes not judges, brothers o'th the bench.
sp.l: The offender comes,
Now they are hot, he shall be sure to smoke for it.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Whither do you hale me? you peas-porridge peasants:
Is this a place for me to come to trial in?
If I had broke the law, as I have not
I am a peer, and do appeal unto
The Kings high seat of justice, publicly.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: And will not our low stool of justice, privily
sp.l: Serve for a traitor? ha.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Yourselves are traitors,
sp.l: In succouring 'gainst the law, a dissolute woman
Whom I command you, in the Kings high name,
To yield into my hands.

sp.speaker: Lol. Pog. Andr.
sp.p: You shall be hanged first.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: By whose authority?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: By the said woman's sir.
sp.l: She is our Queen and her authority is in our hands.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: That speaks you traitors: and the King has law against you and her.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: When you are hanged he has: to the next able
sp.l: Tree with him, and hang him presently.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Villains: you dare not so say.

sp.speaker: Omu.
sp.l: We do all say hang him with one accord:

sp.speaker: Guard
sp.l: If on cord will not do't another shall:
So come away sir.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Stay: hear a speech first.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: You dare not use me thus: dare you take justice one ye?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Yes sir, we can spy
Great faults in noble coats, with half an eye.
What though we nod? does treason therefore think
Justice is addle brained? or though she wink
In us (As thus) that she's asleep ? or say
She take a nap, do ye think she'll sleep for ay?
No, she but dreams a while, to circumvent,
Your veins hopes, with sharper punishment.
For if she be but jogged, no mastiff takes
Swifter or surer vengeance when she wakes.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Ay, hang him, hang him.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Is he not hanged yet?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Without all peradventure the hangman means to hang for him.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Come sir along, never hang backward, for up you must.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Stay him, my speeches will be lost else.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Your long speeches will lose our purpose again, without all peradventure.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Must I be mocked out of my life? and have
My death by hanging made a sport to peasants,
In this blind hole oth' kingdom?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Why thou choplogicall fellow, dost thou not think, there are as good men hanged, and as good sport made of it too, in the blind holes of the kingdom, as in the very eye or open mouth of it? ha!

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Away with him without peradventure

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I am a courtier, and servant to the King.

sp.speaker: Lot
sp.l: Come all the court in all your costly braveries.
And treason in your breech, we'll hang you for your knaveries,
On tree in hempen twine nay if you come
In open arms, up shall you all and some.
For though for tournament your fame's do fly
Run all at tilt on us, we'll draw you dry.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Tell us you are a courtier? we find here
Faults to correct, which you perceive not there.
So, now away with him, I have spoke my best.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: And without all peradventure well said judge Andrea:
How long must we say away with him? ha!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: You hobnailed rascals: can you think that you
Are fit to spy or corrects faults at court?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Stay, a short speech for that, and turn him off.
Your shoes at court are all too fine and thin:
To tread out snuffs and sparks of kindling sin,
Which let alone the rushes may take fire.
Then flame, then burn up higher still, and higher:
You warm you at such fire, 'tis we walk through't
The hobnailed common wealth must tread it out.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: So, now away with him. Hang him first, do ye hear
He has the bast clothes, that will encourage
The hangman the better to turn the rest after him.

sp.speaker: Enl.
sp.l: Whither away with him?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: So, now you see what's become of your fine speeches.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Will ye, 'gainst all my counsels and requests
Persist to pull destruction by taking others lives upon your own?
And seem to carry it as in care for me?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: No, 'tis in care of ourselves, because we know
Not to breed our children honestly without you.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Have I not often counselled and entreated
You would forbear?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Your counsels and entreaties
We are bound to disobey by proclamation:
For we must grant you nothing.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Well found out.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: And therefore if you say, hang not this man we are bound to hang him; we will show ourselves the Kings subjects not yours.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: If you can answer't to the King, 'tis well;
His majesty is here at hand.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Go leave him unto me.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: The King at hand? 'tis time for us to look about us.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Must not we be hanged now?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: It will be so, without all peradventure.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Release your prisoner, set him free, and go send the rest of the confederates.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I was not bound till now
I have no power to move or stir a limb:
Oh sacred Queen, use mercy, in adjudging me,
To present death, to quit me of the torment.
That rages all upon me, all within me.
The sight of you has shot more pains into me
Than I have drops of blood: oh let me die.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: I cannot give thee death: nor will my prayers
Be prevalent for thy cure poor sinful man!
Till thou layst open the cause of thy disease;
(Thy heinous sin) by fair and free confession.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I hope no cure, and therefore ask no life.
But the King's justice to afford me death,
That is no less deserved than desired;
For I confess, this my device was but
To make my way to you, to have murdered you.
sp.stage: Enter two lieutenants, doctor and midwife.
sp.l: Wrought thereunto by Alinda's instigation.
More I confess; the evidence against you,
Whereby you were disposed, was false.
And all these witnesses which now do bring
Addition to my torment, did I hire
Both for their perjury past, and for their late
Attempt upon your life, with the Queen's money.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Do you confess it?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Heaven pardon our misdeed: it is most true.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Heaven grant you all your cures.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: All blessings on the Queen.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: All was confessed before by Fabio and Strozzo.
And you do well to seem so penitent:
I do forgive you: and will plead your pardon unto the King.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Your sacred mercy madam, shall save a life then, to be spent in praises and prayers for your grace.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Go, and pray for grace to mend your lives.
So, let's now to the King.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Now look you about you: cast your coats, and instantly
Hast to the curate, he's preparing sports,
In speech and dance, to entertain the King:
Go and assist him: that must be the way
To gain your pardons.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Come then, let's away,
No longer brothers of the bench we'll be,
But of the revels for his majesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: These troubles over: let us, now
Survey this part of my possession.
I never saw before. I could contemplate
This late neglected piece of my estate,
To be the happiest: sure it is no less,
To those that think on earth there's happiness,
The air disperseth pleasure and the earth
Of fresh delight to every step gives birth.
Here plenty grows, and above it content,
O'er spreads the face of all the continent.
Eulalia, thou art happy, and didst rise,
Not fall from court into this paradise.
Thy can it move my admiration much,
Thy virtue wrought the change, and made it such.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: My lord, the King is sad, what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I am as sad as he, and should be dead,
If he were dead: and therefore no fit member
To make him merry, I: try your vein with him,
Tell him your daughters dying; that may cheer him.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Are you so tart court blain-worm?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yet can I smile in midst of grief to think
How the court malice hath been waved and punished,
By rustical simplicity.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: The sun
Appears again in the King's smiles: observe.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I thank your majesty, that sweet smile revived me,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Who smiled?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Not I, I'm sure did you: or you?
sp.p: There could be no such thing: who dares be merry, when the king's sad?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Yes, here are some now coming, I hear 'em, that are merry in hope to make the King so.

div.head: Scoen. ix.
div.stage: Enter curate richly robbed, and crowned with bays, playing on a fiddle, many school boys with skaerfes and nosegays, etc. then follow Gonzago, dressed and crowned as Queen of the girls, following her: at last Eulalia supported by Lodovico and Andrea: Alphanso, Strozzo, Fabio, D. midwife. The former being all passed over the stage: they kneel to the King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O my Enlalia!

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Still the most humble handmaid
To your high majesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thy words are sweet:
Yet to my guilty sense they are not less
Than thunder bolts; framed of the wrongs I shot
Against the heavenly region of thy mind.
And 'tis but justice that the repercussion
Do strike me dead.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: No passion mighty sir,

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: O my sweet Queen! but I am thunder struck

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Old lad, art there? still sick oth' King's disease.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: If I may presume of any favour, vouchsafe a glance on these.

sp.speaker: Alphonso Stro. Fab. doctor and Mid.
sp.l: Beseech your highness.
sp.stage: Enter curate Gonzago in his hand veiled three or four lasses.

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.l: Thus have you seen great King in best array,
Nostri discipuli have made holiday,
Whilst I their pedagogue or petty King
Present in hand this little royal thing,
yclept their Queen or mistress: certain fallor
For that's the royal school mistress as we call her.
And this her under usher: veiled is she,
Dreading the power of shinning majesty.
Might dazzle her dancing: for nunc est saltandum,
And here are lads and lasses that at random
Have left their works, as we the school et templum,
To follow us; 'tis regis ad exemplum.
The youths are muffled for their better graces,
Though you may like their feet, you'd blame their faces
But I'll not trouble you with long oration,
Because I had but short precogitation.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: His highness thanks you: and hath here disposed
An hundred ducats in this purse enclosed;
Drink it amongst ye to the Kings well faring,
And see there be no falling out ith' sharing
So make your exit.

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.l: Non simus ingrati
Rex et regina semper sint beati.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Stay you a while.
sp.stage: Manent Fabio Strozzo Alphonso doctor and midwife; they all kneel.
sp.l: You know my story, sir, and who have been
My strong abusers, and by me conversed,
Therefore let me petition: royal King
You have by these discovered the abuse
That led you into error: and that light,
Which makes discovery of their black misdeeds,
Will show you to a throne of greater mercy
Than you can give.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I must confess I need it,
Be't as thou wilt Eulalia.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Go then, and thank the King.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Long live the King and Queen.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Here's goodness now.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
I would the devil
had, 'em that thought ill of her.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: And good King pardon me, and my pure brother judges, and sages of the dorp here, that would have hanged those manufactors.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Tis quickly granted.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: And I'll as quickly make them run mad with joy.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: My next suit is, (For now I'm set a-begging ,
You'll pardon your Alinda.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: She is not mine;
Should she recover, as heavens will be done.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Recover? fear not, sir, this trance hast drowned
Her frenzy, and she'll live a sober life.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I shall forgive her,
But she must no more, in her recovery:
Be consort or acquaintance unto me:
But where's posterity now? O my boy!

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Sir you have had but homely entertainment
Yet in my humble dwelling: now I'll show you
(Since you appear so tender and so good
A father) the sweet comfort of a son;
Pray fetch the prince.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You cannot raise from death.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Can you forgive Petrucio that deceived you
In his feigned death, to save a real life:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Forgive? he won me in preserving Sforza,
Let me but see my son, I'll honour him.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: See the most princely virtue that survives.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Lives my Gonzago?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: If you my royal father be not displeased
With me, or my good mother, I shall live.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And long live my sweet prince.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let not my joy confound me! where's Petruccio?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Sforza and he are bringing the entranced Alinda
(Your fair Queen to your presence.)

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: She is no Queen of mine.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: No, hang her, hang her. This, this is the Queen.
A very Queen of hearts: a better title
Crowns not the best of women in our days.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Good Lodovico, may the merited fame of thy fidelity,
While there are Kings on earth, show them to gratify
All trusty servants: love him Gonzago.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Love him? my loyalty preserved,
I shall not desire the prince's love myself
If he not give't to faithful Lodovico,
My true yoke fellow in state and commonwealth.
sp.stage: Enter Sforza and Petruccio, bringing Alinda in a chair, veiled.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But here's the man Gonzago, whom thou owest,
A love of equal value to thy life.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I cannot sir, in duty nevertheless
But fall before your mercy, which I pray for,
That durst assume the hardness to control:
Your majesty command.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: There is a loyalty after my own heart now.
Here a new song, Eulalia unveils Alinda.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Blessed heaven! she lives and wakes I hope in health.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: If she awake to virtue, she is welcome,
Into the the world again: but if she rise
With an ambitious thought of what she was
Or meet the light with a presumptuous look:
That renders her in thought but worthy of it:
By this blessed presence I will yet take leave.
To sink her under earth immediately.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Patience good Sforza, see what she will do.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Where have I been? or how am I brought hither?
Or where I am I know not: but that shall not.
Be unto me a wonder: for I know
Were it revealed, it could not be so strange:
A story as myself was to the world.
How have I wandered in the way of error!
Till I was worn into an airy vapour.
Then wrapped into a cloud: and thence distilled,
Into the earth to find a new creation.
'Tis found: and I am found in better state,
Than I was in, before I lost my duty.
For in this second birth: I find a knowledge
How to preserve it: therefore if an heart
Dissolved in its tears may move your pity
My noble father, (If I may say father,)
Whose blessing and forgiveness I entreat,
Let not your frown destroy my future hopes.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: What a rich sound were this now, were it real!

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: As you may think I honour virtue Sforza,
I do believe 'tis really unfeigned.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: It is heaven's goodness to your grace then madam.
The more to vindicate your injured virtue.
And manifest your merits to the world,
Thou art mine own again Alinda.

sp.speaker: Eal
sp.l: Note her further.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: My suit is next to you King, Queen, and prince,
Whose love, whose piety, whose innocence,
I have too much abused that to appeal,
my trespasses at large by due confession.
I should appear but more impertinent to each eye and ear.
My suit is therefore (Though you not forget
I ever was) you will be pleased to think,
There is not an Alinda in the world.
So give me leave to leave it: and in this,
I beg my father's aid, to be removed
Back to my country Naples; and in that,
Into the Magdalene nunnery at Lucera,
To spend this life in tears for my amiss,
And holy prayers for eternal bliss.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: So thou art mine for ever.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: She has anticipated my great purpose,
For on the reconcilement of this difference,
I vowed my after life unto the monastery
Of holy Augustinians at Solanto.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: O mighty sir!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Tis not to be gainsaid.
So haste we to Nicosia, where (My son)
In lieu of former wrongs, I'll yield thee up my crown and kingdom.
Your virtuous mother (Whom may you for ever
Honour for her piety) with these true
Statesmen, will enable you to govern well.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Who makes a doubt of that?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And let your study, sir, be ever watchful
To cherish virtue, as to punish vice.
And see that you considerative be
Of Sforza, in the wrongs he felt by me.
His was the greatest loss.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Sir, I have won:
My wrongs are drowned in her conversion.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Good Sforza, see her placed as she desires,
in that religious order. I have now
Plighted my troth to heaven, and so has she.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: O may (Sir) such wedlock ne'er broken be.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now with such melting silence as sweet souls
From body's part to immortality,
May we for better life divided be.

div.closer: Dedit deus his quoque finem. Ric. Brome.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Through much distress, and many perilous ways
Our Queen at last with more than conquering bays
Is crowned with hearts: but now she falls again,
And we, except her glory you maintain.
Our good depends on you then, thus it stands;
She cheers our hearts, if she but gain your hands.

list.head: Books printed for hen. Brome at the gun in ivy-lane.
list.item: The souls conflict, being eight sermons, six whereof were preached at Oxford.
The Queen's exchange, a comedy, by Richard Brome.
Two essays of love and marriage.
The grand impostor examined, or the life and trial of James Nayler.
The souls turnkey, being a conference betwixt Mr. Hanum and Mr. Tuke moderator of Gr. Coll. in London.
Poems, epistles and epigrams, on several persons and occasions, by nobody must know whom, are to be had everybody knows where, and for anybody knows what.
Dr. Brown's sepulchral urns, and gardens of Cyprus.

list.head: Books now in the press: which will shortly be extant.
list.item: The affinity of sacred liturgies, by Hamon l' estrange, esq
Five new comedies which were never before published, by Richard Brome.
A learned and desired commentary on the whole epistle to the Philippians. By Nath. Tucker late preacher of the gospel at Portsmouth.
Adam out of Eden, or an abstract of remarkable observations, touching the improving of husbandry: by John speed, etc.

div.p: Pag. 9. l. 13. f. is read in p. 11 ▪ l. 5. f. Nignion. r. minion. p. 28. l. 6. f. Hor. r. Lod. p. 38. l. 13. and 14. Ent. Sforza. p. 61. l. 20. for and r. in. p. 68. l. antepenult. f. mine r. my. p. 69. l. 5. f. shalt be King. r. shalt. King. p. 75. l. 19. f. inspired r. has inspired. p. 76. f. but r. bate. l. 32. p. 80. l. 26. f. said, r. have said. p. 83. l. 4. r. lol. p. 84. l. 18. deal countr. p. 94. l. r. exeunt. p. 95. l. 23. f. speaks r. speak. and l. 29. f. in. r. is in. p. 97. f. they. r. thy. p. 97. f. speaks. r. speak. p. 115. l. 13. f. to their r. to be their and l. 18. deal Eul. p. 116. l. 24. p. 119. l. 3. f. on. r. one, and l. 6. f. one, r. on p. 122. l. 5. deal to my.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
